The Johns Hopkins NF1 Biospecimen Reposi.description: [From JHU:] The Comprehensive Neurofibromatosis Center at Johns Hopkins serves a large volume of patients affected by NF1.  We have an IRB-approved research studyfor banking NF1-associated tumors including plexiform neurofibromas, MPNST, and blood fractions from patients with NF1.  We also collect and bank any malignancy from a patient with NF1 including breast cancer, GIST, and brain cancer. The goal of this project is to establish a comprehensively annotated biorepository of tissue and blood fractions for use in NF1 research.  Tumors included in our biospecimen bank include: cutaneous neurofibroma, diffuse infiltrating neurofibroma, plexiform neurofibroma, atypical neurofibroma, and MPNST.  Our goal is to increase availability of these tissues to the NF1 research community through scientific resource and data sharing.

CTF Biobank.description: [From DHART-SPORE:] The Children’s Tumor Foundation (CTF) human tissue biobank is an open collection of NF1, NF2, and schwannomatosis tissue samples donated by patients.

Coriell Institute for Medical Research B.description: Coriell Institute for Medical Research Biobank provides the global scientific community with the most trusted biological samples available. The samples housed at Coriell represent the genetic diversity of humankind and offer researchers samples taken from individuals with the most common and also the rarest genetic diseases known to science. We offer a variety of materials, including cell lines, DNA, and state-of-the-art induced pluripotent stem cells.

Children's Hospital of Philadelphia Biob.description: This project establishes a standardized biorepository using samples from two completed CDMRP NF Clinical Trials Consortium (NFCTC) studies (NF108: Phase II Study of Binimetinib in Children and Adults With NF1 Plexiform Neurofibromas and NF105: Cabozantinib for Plexiform Neurofibromas in Subjects With NF1 in Children and Adults). The repository is built to support future research on tumor biomarkers as related to neurofibromas, their response to various treatments and pharmacodynamic dosing.
